meanings.definition: Ability to live, grow, or develop
meanings.sent1: The plant's viability was evident as it sprouted new leaves.
meanings.sent2: The doctor assessed the baby's viability after the premature birth.
meanings.sent3: The viability of the seed was put to the test in the fertile soil.
meanings.sent4: The viability of the business idea blossomed into a successful venture.
meanings.sent5: The viability of the ecosystem depended on the balance of its components.

meanings.definition: Ability to work or be successful
meanings.sent1: The team discussed the viability of their project during the meeting.
meanings.sent2: The viability of the new strategy was questioned by the board members.
meanings.sent3: The viability of the plan sparked a lively debate among colleagues.
meanings.sent4: The viability of the investment led to significant profits for the company.
meanings.sent5: The viability of the solution became apparent after successful implementation.

meanings.definition: Ability to exist or be used
meanings.sent1: The architect considered the viability of the design for the new building.
meanings.sent2: The viability of the old machinery was a concern for the factory manager.
meanings.sent3: The viability of the ancient artifact puzzled the historians.
meanings.sent4: The viability of the technology determined its adoption in the market.
meanings.sent5: The viability of the resource influenced its conservation efforts.
